content.description: Winds its way up and left, ending up on an upper arete. A bit sandy, as implied.
content.location: The last route on the lower end of the Spaghetti western wall.

content.description: Put up your Dukes! Tricky as a snake in the grass, pardner. And, as the name implies, gritty, at least in the lower half of the route.
content.location: Second route on the right end of Walt's Wall.

content.description: Has some ledges to watch out for.
content.protection: Five or six bolts to shared anchor with Soy Beefcake
content.location: Walk up behind the big rock on the right side of Walt's Wall.

content.protection: 7 bolts with gray hangers to chain anchors. Or skip the bolts and climb it on a single rack to #3 BD camalot.
content.location: In the corner just a couple paces right of Toy Gun Show.

climbs.name: Soy Beefcake
climbs.fa: Jason Halladay and Mark Schraad, May 2007.

content.description: Sort of climbs the left arete of the short face on the right side of Walt's Wall; the crux of the climb is kind of off-balance, and if you climb it straight on rather than using the features to the left, it's likely to seem harder. If you keep going past the anchors, you're doing the "Hamburger Helper" extension.
content.protection: 6 (?) bolts to shared anchor with Toy Gun Show
content.location: Behind the big rock at the base of Walt's Wall; just right of the chimney.

climbs.name: Smart Cowboy
climbs.fa: Josh Smith, Gary Parker, Alan Novak

content.description: Tricky climbing. Climb smart to keep it 5.10.  The crux comes pulling off the ledge half way up, into the shallow left leaning dihedral.
content.protection: Nine bolts with close clips. Chains.
content.location: Just left of the chimney that marks the upper end of Spaghetti Western Wall.

content.description: The crux is in the middle and is quite reachy. Probably 12a if you're under 5'8' and easier than 11 if you're over 6'. Sneaky climbing right off the ground.
content.location: Just left of the cave at the upstream end of the area.

climbs.name: Reprimanda
climbs.fa: Andrea Cutter, Scott Beguin, Rick Bradshaw, Ken Kisiel, and Teague Barto

content.description: This route is in two pitches because of the very large ledge in the middle. P1 is 11a, P2 is about the same, but the route is significantly harder because of rope drag if you link the two pitches. If you do link the pitches, consider skipping clipping the anchor.
content.location: Below Spaghetti Western Wall, on an independent tower.

content.description: Climb the 5.10 version of Powder Monkey up to the mid-anchors, get a rest and power thru the harder crimp moves past a fixed draw to the higher anchors.
content.location: Extension of Powder Monkey

content.description: Fun 5.10 to the first anchor set, and some wicked 12a moves off the ledge to the second anchor set.
content.protection: 7 bolts to the first two-bolt anchor. A few more bolts protect the Powder Monkey Extension above the first anchor to a second two-bolt anchor above.
content.location: Middle/left of the Spaghetti Western Wall.

content.description: Shoots for a white dihedral, then goes up over a small roof. Fun climbing with good air potential at the roof. The upper slab has proven to be the crux for a few folks.
content.location: Look for the white dihedral on Walt's Wall; shoot for that.

content.description: The crux is at the top, on the slab, clipping the anchors. This route is best done as a lead-follow because it starts on the arete and sort of curves around. Lowering off and to clean your draws creates a great deal of drag and a bit of a swing as you near the ground.
content.location: Left end of Walt's Wall.

content.description:
An extension to Blue Shadows. Once you reach the anchor on Blue Shadows, clip a draw to the left chain (to reduce drag later) and continue up and left. Getting to a couple of good underclings leading to a great side pull is the crux. Then bust through the roofish-feature involving a couple steep moves.  Once above the roof, continue up on the slab to the anchor.  

  Ned Nederlander flew a Tuppan-601 plane in Little Neddy Goes to War.
content.protection: 4 bolts on the extension--12 total to a two-bolt anchor with carabiners. A 60m rope is advised. Watch out with a 50m rope--it may just barely make it.
content.location: Climb Blue Shadows and then keep going for maximum fun.

content.description: This is the extension to Soy Beefcake; goes up the headwall above the anchor. It's a bit crumbly above the ledge with the anchors, but the climbing above that is fun.
content.location: Just right of Walt's Wall. Start behind a rock.

climbs.name: Demanda
climbs.fa: Josh Smith, Gary Parker, Jason Halladay

content.description: Has a crux down low, and then has pretty fun, rambly climbing. This route is kind of squeezed in with Pitchfork and Pale Rider, and about a third of the way up all three routes converge. Stick with the middle line if you want the climbing to stay at 5.9.
content.location: On the left end of Walt's Wall.

content.description: Being taller than 5'9" helps you up this one. Amazing climbing up dishes on bullet rock. The bolts are spaced out a bit more than on some of the other routes, so be careful.
content.protection: Seven bolts to a two-bolt anchor
content.location: The first route on the uphill end of the Spaghetti Western Wall. Chains 3/4 of the way up.

content.description: A little gritty with some crumbly rock in the middle, but pretty fun. It arcs left.
content.location: Second route downstream from the cave at the upper end of the wall.

climbs.name: Code of the West
climbs.fa: Aaron Miller, Josh Smith, James Hunter

content.description: The crack that splits the middle of the Spaghetti Western Wall. One of the best hard crack lines around. A bolt protects the first crux and keeps you off a ledge, and a couple more help you through the slab to the rest of the crack. Don't stop at the Cowboy Up anchors; keep going to the second set at the top.
content.protection: Gear to #2 and three bolts. Heavy on the finger sizes. Anchors.
content.location: Towards the left side of the Spaghetti Western Wall.

content.description: A bit dirty but with a pretty fun roof at the top. Go right at the roof to the chains.
content.location: The obvious corner between Blue Shadows and Pale Rider.

content.description: Tricky all the way up, with the crux at the top. Has SS glue-in bolts. Bolts are spaced out a little more than some of the other routes. The first route to go in here (2004).
content.protection: 8 bolts to chains (with lowering carabiners, don't steal these!)
content.location: Look for the huge gold chains on Walt's Wall; it's also set off from the other routes by the SS glue-in bots.

content.description:
Blue Shadows is a decent route up beautiful and smooth rock. Start up in the corner/trough that is the start of Cheap Whiskey and clip a high first bolt with beige hanger well to the right of the corner crack. Pull the steep move past the bolt and scramble up and left on 4th class terrain to a big ledge. A small or medium cam could possibly protect this scramble but it's easy terrain on good rock.  

  From the ledge, reach up to clip a bolt and pull up onto the horizontal.  Figure out the best way to move, left or right on side pulls, on bullet, smooth faces between good horizontal stances to the anchors just below the big roof above.  This route is probably more difficult for shorter climbers. 

  If you're just getting warmed up by the time you reach the anchor, keep going for four more bolts above into Ned Flies a Stick. This extension is quite fun. 

youtube.com/watch?v=4HdlYVKâ€¦
content.protection: 7 bolts to a two bolts anchor with chains/carabiners.
content.location: Start as for Cheap Whiskey in the corner but then cross left to the ledge following the bolts to the right of Smart Cowboy.

content.description: Grab the right side of the arete up high. The crux is right in the middle, on tiny edges.
content.location: This is the right arete on Walt's Wall.

content.description:
This wall is predominantly vertical and offers a good variety of climbing in more moderate grades than the Monster Wall. Watch for loose rock and expect some grit.   

  The climbs are numbered from right to left, to coincide with the               

Overview of the Spaghetti Western Wall area as of summer 2008.       .
